transcripts.text: I am a female to male to female detransitioner.  The biggest thing that I regret is the change in my voice.

Hey everyone!  So today's video is one that I'm actually extremely proud of.  I sat down and I had a discussion with a detransitioner.  Her name is Elle.  She transitioned to a boy at 15 and is now transitioning back into a woman.  Now I've talked about detransitioning a few times on my channel, but I've never spoken in my life with someone who has actually detransitioned.  And detransitioning is something that is incredibly taboo within the trans community.  A lot of people who tell their stories of detransitioning are bullied and shamed and silenced.  Some trans people take it as an attack on them when detransitioners tell their story.  I can only imagine that they feel delegitimized in some way, that acknowledging that people make a mistake when transitioning makes people think that they made a mistake.  I'm here to say that I'm a trans woman who is incredibly happy with my transition.  I would not change a thing, never will, but I feel like it's only right to discuss the opposite end of the spectrum.  If we're gonna tell these stories about how transition works for everyone, which I don't personally believe, I feel like we should also be fair and discuss people who thought it worked for them and didn't, especially kids, teenagers, which is the case of Elle.  So I encourage you guys to watch to the end.  Please reserve any harsh comments or judgments on Elle.  Just like all of us, she's just trying to figure stuff out.  And without further ado, here's Elle.  So you are the first detransitioner I've ever spoken to, which is crazy because I've talked about it before, but I've never actually spoken to someone who's been through it.  So correct me if I'm wrong, but you transitioned from female to male and now back to female.  Is that the right terminology?

Yep, that is right.  I was born female and I'm going back to female now.  I identified as trans from age 15 until about five months ago.  So that was about four years of my life.  Wow.  Yeah, I transitioned.  I took testosterone for three years, but I never got any surgeries or anything.

What was it that made you feel as if transitioning was the right thing for you?  And then on the flip side, what was it that made you come to the ultimate realization that detransitioning was the right move for you?

I think it was a combination of a lot of big things.  Mostly, I'd say the biggest factors were I didn't have any friends and I wasn't going to school.  And so I didn't really interact with anyone in my day-to-day life besides my family.  I'd say also I had a lot of mental health problems when I was going through puberty.  And I think I kind of look at it as like.  my puberty was like medicalized because when I was having a lot of like mental health problems when I started puberty.  Was like my parents took me to the doctor and they were like, you know Like my kid like doesn't want to get out of bed like is really depressed like what's going on?  And they just I think they just tried to medicate me and put me on a lot of pills and like didn't really try to like Dig into why I was feeling that way.  so from a young age I kind of felt like oh something is just wrong with me like mentally and like I just was trying to figure out what it was right.  and When I found out, like, about, like, that being trans was a thing when I was 14, I was like, this has to be, like, the thing that's wrong with me.

I actually, on some level, relate to that because when I was younger, I got diagnosed with, um, all types of things because I had behavioral issues, OCD, ADHD, all these things that I definitely don't have.  And as an adult, I recognize that I just had behavioral issues and I had stuff I was going through at home.  And sometimes doctors do just throw you on anything, which is really, really bad.  So you feel as though the issues you were having as a kid set you on a journey to where you were looking for the fix and you ended up feeling like transgenderism was the fix.  You know, there are a lot of changes, bodily changes that come from medical transition, whether it be hormonally or surgery.  You said you haven't had surgery.  What are some of the effects of hormones, testosterone, that you probably, I would assume, regret now?

The biggest thing that I regret is the change in my voice.  That, since I started as a teenager at 16, I was still able to get like a cis man's voice, like a very malleable, deep voice.  And so having to like come to the realization that I don't want to present as a man anymore and having to deal with the fact that I once had like like a perfectly normal teenage girl voice and just let testosterone destroy it.  That's how I feel.  And it's really hard to deal with that.  And then the other thing that is like, it bothers me, but it's not that hard to deal with is like, I have some facial hair.  And it's really, it's not that bad because I only have to shave like every three or four days, which in the grand scheme of things is okay.
And there's laser hair removal and stuff like that.
Right, yeah.  So like three years is, especially as a teenager, like that's a long time to be going through hormone treatment.
It does a lot in three years.
It does, yeah.

I started my transition actually technically as an adult.  I was 20.  And I mean, even the changes from that was like a lot.  So it's even more so when you're a teenager.  So yeah, I can only imagine.

Yeah, I'm just like... I feel positive most days because I know like I'm still really young, like I'm 20 now.  And so I get to see like the effects of like the estrogen just like coming back into my system.  And I'm still, I've still like, it's, it's changed my face a lot already.  And people will see me and they'll kind of be like, wow, you look really different.  And that's cool to see already.  But yeah, like, The voice, like, that's just, oh my gosh.  Like every day, I just like, whenever I go out and I'm like, yeah, like I look totally feminine, but then it's like, the second I talk, it's like, oh, I get a weird look.

Do you find that there is a negative stigma toward even speaking about detransitioning?  Because whenever I talk about it, I think it's an important component to discussing transgenderism.  You know what I mean?  If you look on YouTube, there are almost as many detransitioners as there are trans people on YouTube.  I mean, just type in ID transitioned and there's a plethora of videos.  But for some reason, when you talk about it, there's a great backlash in the trans community who I think a lot of them feel like it minimizes trans people.

Do you find it hard to talk about it to other trans people?  I've actually, yeah, I've thought about that a lot as well because I remember being in the community, being so sure about my identity at one point and seeing things from, like, I would look at Reddit and I would see, like, maybe one person posted said, like, I'm a detransitioner.  It would almost feel like a personal attack on me.  Like, Like you went through what I went through and I'm so happy, but you're not like, and, and, and what does that mean for me?  And so I think a lot of people might look at like detransitioning stories and think like, well, they're like, you know, they're saying something about me, you know, and like seeing it as like, It's got a connotation that it's transphobic to talk about detransition.
Yeah.  So would it be safe to say that you kind of figured out that you were a tomboy rather than a trans man?
I think if I could go back, I would tell myself that I didn't have to be a certain way to be a woman.
Yeah.
I would say, like, you can dress however you want.  You can wear makeup.  You can not wear makeup.  you don't have to change the way that your body looks or the way that you are.

Right.  Cause I feel like, you know, being transgender is about so much more than I'm a girly guy or I'm a feminine boy.  And I feel like if, if you're only sort of reasoning as to doing something as drastic as transition is that I don't feel masculine when I'm a boy or I don't feel feminine when I'm a girl, that's very surface level.  And yeah, Personally, you know, the way the community is going is that is kind of the guidelines.  It's like, oh, you feel vulnerable to transition.  And I feel like going forward, we're going to see more and more.  And I've always said this.  We're going to see more and more detransitioning stories.  And you can see it now even on YouTube.  I remember – A year or two ago, if you Google detransitioners, there's like maybe three or four kind of famous cases and they got no attention.  And now when you search it up on YouTube, just in the past few months, there's like an explosion of YouTubers coming out and saying, I detransitioned.

And I think that's a very important thing that we need to think about is how many like young impressionable people are getting on the internet and getting into like support groups or communities that are just like totally like one-sided and just like have no other like alternatives.

so i think I think a lot of young trans people and people who are maybe curious if they are trans, their first step is to join trans support forums or trans group chats or whatever.  And sometimes getting only one side of things can distort your view on what the right decision is for you.  That's something I always personally battle with is the fact that, you know, I'm trans and I'm on YouTube and I have a large platform and I worry myself about maybe glamorizing it or making it seem as something that is the right move for everybody, which is why I often try to say, like, it was the right move for me.  It doesn't mean it was the right move for you.  And it's also about saying it doesn't mean that transitioning as a whole needs to be thrown out and that it never works for people.  Because personally, I feel it does work for people.  But we have to allow nuance in the conversation to say, for some people, it doesn't.  And this is another thing.  This is another reason why... I hold my stance against very young kids transitioning because this whole idea of kids transitioning is predicated upon the belief that you always know, right?  It's on the basis that when you know, you know.  When you say it, it means it's 100% true.  It's not the case.  I'm sure you agree.  Yeah.

Yeah.  I think one person who comes out and says, like, I transitioned as a child and now I regret it.  I think that's enough to say that no one should be able to.  Like, how how do we know?  How do we know who is going to grow up and regret it?  We don't.  And I think this is a decision that has to be made by an adult who can think about the future, who can think about every little thing that's going to come along with it.  Even as a 16-year-old, I didn't think about how it would affect me three years from now, like five years from then.  I didn't think about that.  It was only what mattered to me at that moment.

And that's, I mean, and that's how the teenage mind operates.  I mean, it's scientifically, they don't have the foresight that adults have.  And like I said, it's a nuanced conversation because you have people that transition when they're 12, 13 or even younger and they live happy lives and they're great when they're older because that can be true as well.  But when you open the floodgates and say, because there are success stories that people everyone just knows when they know i mean to me it's almost like superstition.  it's almost like believing that it's some like otherworldly thing.  do you have any sort of final um thoughts?

i do want to say that i think no matter like what you're going through there's always a reason to be positive.  And time heals everything.  The way that I always make myself feel better if I'm ever feeling bad about myself is just that in six months from now, a year from now, 10 years from now, whatever I'm thinking about, it's not going to matter at all.  I'm going to have completely different priorities.  And I'm going to have other stuff going on.  I'm just, I, that always helps me to put things into perspective.

Right.  That's awesome.  Thank you so much, Al.  This has been incredibly insightful as someone who's talked about this, but never spoken to someone who's experienced it firsthand.  And I just appreciate your story and thank you so much.
Yeah.  Thank you so much.
